title: Generation of recombinant vaccinia virus and analysis of virus-induced cell death
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Vaccinia virus infection and DNA transfection
Timing: 5 days
In this procedure, we will infect BS-C-1 cells with vRB12, followed by transfection of pRB21 containing our gene of interest. BS-C-1 cells are chosen because they form large visible plaques on monolayer infection (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]). This first step will generate heterogeneous virions. Further selection will be necessary to isolate recombinant vaccinia virus for subsequent subcloning and expansion.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1059-Fig1.jpg
Figure 1. Workflow for recombinant vaccinia virus generation
Infection with vRB12
Seed BS-C-1 cells at 2.5 × 105 cells per well in 1 mL Complete MEM-10 medium on 12-well tissue culture plate.
Culture cells for 16–20 h in humidified incubator at 37oC and 5% CO2. The cells should be at 90% or higher confluency at the time of infection.
Thaw vRB12 stock virus on ice.
Dilute virus to 0.5 × 105 pfu/mL using MEM-2.5 medium.
Aspirate medium from the cell monolayer. Replace it with 0.5 mL diluted virus from 1d.
Incubate at 37°C and 5% CO2 incubator for 2 h.
DNA transfection
Prewarm Opti-MEM and LT1 transfection reagent to 22oC.
Prepare transfection master mix containing 100 μL Opti-MEM, 3 μL TransIT®-LT1 Transfection Reagent and 1 μg pRB21-GFP-vIRD.
Incubate the DNA transfection mixture at 22oC for 15 min.
Retrieve virus-infected cells from step 1f.
Remove medium from virus-infected BS-C-1 cells.
Wash the infected cells twice by rinsing the cells with 1 mL of 1X PBS.
Add 1 mL MEM-2.5 medium to the cells.
Add the DNA transfection mixture dropwise to the cells.
Gently rock the cells back and forth to evenly mix the transfection mixture with the cells.
Incubate the cells in a 37°C, 5% CO2 incubator for 24 h.
Replace medium with 1 mL MEM-2.5 medium.

Incubate the cells for 2 days in a 37°C, 5% CO2 incubator.
Harvest of viral supernatant
Prewarm Opti-MEM in 37°C water bath.
Remove 500 μL of culture medium from each well.
Dislodge the infected cells in the remaining culture medium using disposable cell scraper.
Transfer the cell suspension to a 2 mL sterile screw-top microcentrifuge tubes.
Place the cells in in dry ice for 5 min, followed by placing them in a 37°C water bath for 5 min. Vortex for 5 s.
Repeat the freeze/thaw two more times for a total of three freeze/thaw cycles.
Store the viral supernatants at −80oC.
Note: The viral supernatants will contain cellular debris. It is advisable to remove the debris before proceeding to selection of recombinant virus. This can be achieved by centrifugation for 5 minutes at 650 × g at 22oC.
Critical: Disposable items such as tissue culture plates, pipet tips, Eppendorf tubes that have been exposed to virus or virus-infected materials should be treated with 0.05% diluted bleach solution prior to disposal.
Selection of recombinant virus
Timing: 2 weeks
The procedure here describes the selection of recombinant vaccinia virus based on visual plaque size. A total of three rounds of selection will be needed to ensure isolation of homogeneous population of recombinant viral progenies (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1059-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. Workflow for selection of recombinant virus
Seed BS-C-1 cells at 5 × 105 cells in 2 mL complete MEM-10 medium per well on 6-well plate. Incubate in a 37°C, 5% CO2 incubator for 24 h.
Replace medium with 1 mL of pre-warmed MEM-2.5 medium per well.
Thaw viral supernatants from step 3 on ice. To each well, dispense 100 μL, 10 μL, 1 μL or 0.1 μL of the thawed viral supernatants to the cell monolayer.

Note: Since the titer of the viral supernatant is unknown, the 10-fold serial dilution of the virus ensures that large distinct plaques can be easily identified. If the plaque count is too high, further dilutions can be used.
Incubate in a 37°C, 5% CO2 incubator for 2 h.
Remove medium and replace it with 2 mL pre-warmed MEM-2.5 containing 2.5% methylcellulose.
Note: The methylcellulose is viscous and is included to minimize spreading of viral progenies from the original infected cells. To avoid air bubbles, add the MEM-2.5% methylcellulose at an angle along the edge of the well.
Incubate in a 37°C, 5% CO2 incubator for 48 h.
Dispense 0.5 mL of pre-warmed MEM-2.5 medium to sterile Eppendorf tubes.
Retrieve the plate from step 9 from the incubator. Identify large plaques, which should be visible after 48–72 h of infection. Mark the location of the plaques at the bottom of the plate using a marker pen.
Using 200 μL pipet tip attached to a P200 pipette, carefully scrape the plaque area with the tip while drawing up the content of the plaque.
Transfer the content to Eppendorf tube containing 500 μL MEM-2.5.
Vortex the Eppendorf tube.
Subject the tube to three cycles of freeze/thaw three times as described in step 3.
Save the released virus at −80oC freezer until next round of selection.
Repeat steps 4–16 two more times for a total of three rounds of plaque selection. The additional rounds of subcloning ensures purity of the resulting viral stocks.

Note: The methylcellulose helps to prevent spreading of viruses within the well and to allow clear distinct plaques to form. Therefore, avoid disturbing the plate during the 48-hour incubation period. In some cases, longer incubation time of up to 72 hours may be required for clear large plaques to form. We typically collect three to five plaques for each round of selection.
Amplification of recombinant virus
Timing: 2–3 weeks
This protocol describes the stepwise amplification and production of recombinant vaccinia virus.
6-Well plate amplification
Seed 5 × 105 BS-C-1 cells in 2 mL complete MEM-10 per well in a 6-well plate. Incubate at 37°C, 5% CO2 for 24 h.
Dilute 250 μL of recombinant virus from step 17 with 750 μL MEM-2.5.
Dispense the diluted virus to the BS-C-1 cells.
Incubate at 37°C, 5% CO2 for 30 min.
Add 1 mL of MEM-2.5 to each well, incubate in 37°C, 5% CO2 incubator for 48 h.
Remove 1 mL of medium.
Scrape the cells in the remaining 1 mL of medium with disposable cell scraper.
Transfer the cells and supernatant to sterile Eppendorf tube.
Subject the infected cell mixture to three cycles of freeze/thaw. Vortex the tube after each thaw cycle.
Save the viral supernatant in −80oC freezer.
T25 flask amplification
Seed 1.5 × 106 of BS-C-1 cells in complete MEM medium in a T25 flask. Incubate at 37°C, 5% CO2 for 24 h.
Dilute 500 μL of amplified recombinant virus from step 27 with 1.5 mL MEM-2.5.
Dispense the diluted virus to the BS-C-1 cells in T25 flask.
Incubate virus with cells at 37°C, 5% CO2 for 30 min.
Add 3 mL of MEM-2.5 to the flask.
Incubate at 37°C, 5% CO2 for 48 h.
Scrape the cells with disposable cell scraper. Transfer the supernatant to 15 mL conical tube.

Spin the cells down at 1800 × g for 5 min. Resuspend the cell pellet in 1 mL MEM-2.5.
Note: Biosafety caps should be used for the rotor buckets during centrifugation to prevent leakage of infected materials.
Subject the cell mixture to three cycles of freeze/thaw. Vortex the tube after each thaw cycle.
Save the viral supernatant in −80oC freezer.
Validation of protein expression by recombinant vaccinia virus
Timing: 5 days
Note: We typically will validate protein expression after expansion of the virus in T25 flasks. However, validation of protein expression can also be performed at the 6-well stage.
Seed 2.5 × 105 L929 cells in 1 mL of complete DMEM-10 medium in each well of a 12-well plate. Incubate at 37°C, 5% CO2 for 24 h.
Add 10 μL of the amplified recombinant virus from step 37 with 1 mL MEM-2.5.
Add the diluted virus to the cells. Incubate at 37°C, 5% CO2 for 2 h.
Replace medium with 1 mL of complete DMEM-10 medium per well.
Incubate infected cells at 37°C, 5% CO2 for 18 h.
Wash the infected cells by rinsing the cells twice with 1 mL 1X PBS at 4oC.
Add 100 μL RIPA lysis buffer supplemented with 1X Complete protease inhibitor cocktail and 1X phosphatase inhibitor cocktail.
Transfer the cells to Eppendorf tube.
Homogenate the cell lysate by pressing it through an insulin syringe five times.
Boil in 1X LDS Sample buffer for 5 min.
Load the cell lysates on 4%–20% SurePAGE Bis-Tris precast gels.
Transfer the resolved cell lysates onto nitrocellulose membrane.
Perform Western blot using anti-GFP antibody conjugated to HRP. Representative result is shown in Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3].
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1059-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Confirmation of vIRD expression by Western blot

L929 cells were infected with the indicated viruses for 18 h. Expression of GFP-vIRD was determined by Western blot. Expression of actin was used to confirm equal loading of proteins.
Large-scale production of recombinant vaccinia virus stock
Timing: 3 days
Seed 1 × 107 BS-C-1 cells in complete MEM-10 medium in T175 flask. Incubate at 37°C, 5% CO2 for 24 h.
Dilute 500 μL of recombinant virus from step 37 with 4.5 mL MEM-2.5.
Add the diluted virus to the cells in the flask. Incubate infected cells at 37°C, 5% CO2 for 30 min.
Add 25 mL of MEM-2.5 to each flask. Incubate at 37°C, 5% CO2 for 48 h.
Scrape cells with disposable cell scraper and transfer the culture supernatant to 50 mL conical tube.
Spin down the cells at 1800 × g for 5 min.
Note: Biosafety caps should be used for the rotor buckets during centrifugation to prevent leakage of infected materials.
Resuspend cell pellet in 2 mL MEM-2.5.
Subject the infected cell mixture to three cycles of freeze/thaw. Vortex the tube after each thaw cycle.
Aliquot the viral supernatant into 2 mL screw cap freezing vials.
Save the viral supernatant in −80oC freezer.
Determination of viral titer
Timing: 4 days
Before using the recombinant virus to determine the effect of virus-induced cell death, it is important to determine the viral tier using monolayer plaque assay (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1059-Fig4.jpg
Figure 4. Workflow for viral titer determination
Seed 5 × 105 Vero cells per well in 2 mL complete MEM-10 medium in 6-well plate. Incubate at 37°C, 5% CO2 for 24 h.
Thaw the virus from step 60 on ice.
Perform serial dilution of the virus stock as follows:

Add 10 μL of stock virus solution to 990 μL of MEM-2.5. Mix by gently pipetting the content several times. This is the 1:100 (10−2) dilution.
Transfer 20 μL of the diluted virus in step 63a with 180 μL of MEM-2.5. Mix by gently pipetting the content several times. This is the 1:1,000 (10−3) dilution.
Prepare the 10−4, 10−5, 10−6 and 10−7 dilutions as in step 63b.
Aspirate the culture medium in the 6-well plate. Replace with 1 mL MEM-2.5 for each well.
Add 100 μL of the serially diluted virus from step 63 to each well, leaving the last well as control without virus. Incubate at 37°C, 5% CO2 for 2 h.
Remove the medium. Add 2 mL complete MEM to each well. Incubate at 37°C, 5% CO2 for 48 h.
Wash cells twice with 2 mL 1X PBS.
Add 1 mL 4% paraformaldehyde solution in PBS. Fix the cells for 30 min at 22oC.
Aspirate the paraformaldehyde solution. Add 1 mL of crystal violet staining solution to each well. Rock the plate gently to ensure that the solution covers the whole well.
Aspirate the crystal violet solution. Rinse the wells under a running tap to remove the crystal violet solution.
Count the number of plaques in the wells with clear and distinct plaques. A representative image of the clear plaques is shown in Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5].
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1059-Fig5.jpg
Figure 5. Representative plaque assay
Note that the plaques in the wells with lowest dilution factors were too numerous and not discrete enough for accurate counting. In this example, only the 10−6 and 10−7 wells were counted. The PFUs from the two wells were averaged to obtain the final PFU.
Calculate the plaque forming unit (PFU) using the formula:

P F U =  N u m b e r  o f  p l a q u e s  x  1  d i l u t i o n  f a c t o r    x  1  v o l u m e   ( m l )     
Determination of virus-induced cell death
Timing: 3 days
This protocol describes the functional characterization of the effect of expression of the necroptosis inhibitor vIRD in vaccinia virus-induced necroptosis (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]). We use the Incucyte live cell imaging system to measure cell death. However, other methods can be used to enumerate cell death in response to infection by the recombinant vaccinia virus.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1059-Fig6.jpg
Figure 6. Workflow of cell death measurement using live cell imaging
Seed 1.25 x 105 L929 cells in 1 mL complete DMEM medium per well in 24-well plate. Incubate at 37°C, 5% CO2 for 24 h.
Note: L929 cells produce autocrine TNF in response to virus infection (Liu et al., 2021[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3]). Therefore, there is no need to add exogenous TNF to the infected cells. However, other cells such as mouse embryonic fibroblasts do not produce autocrine TNF. In this situation, recombinant TNF will have to be added to the infected cells to trigger necroptosis.
Thaw the recombinant vaccinia virus rVACV-GFP-vIRD on ice. In this example, we will infect the cells with a multiplicity of infection (moi) of 2.
Note: We found that moi of 2 leads to about 30% virus-induced cell death by 24 hours post-infection. This allows us to measure the effect of genes that increase or decrease virus-induced cell death. However, the moi should be determined empirically based on the amount of autocrine TNF produced and the sensitivity to virus-induced necroptosis. If the cell line does not produce autocrine TNF, cell death can be induced with exogenous TNF.

To 300 μL DMEM-2.5, add the required volume of rVACV-GFP-vIRD using the formula below:
  V o l u m e  o f  s t o c k  v i r u s  n e e d e d   ( m l )  =   M O I  x  c e l l  n u m b e r   P F U  o f  s t o c k   ( m l )     
Replace the culture medium with DMEM-2.5 containing the virus from step 75. Incubate at 37°C, 5% CO2 for 2 h.
Remove the medium containing the virus. Replace it with 500 μL complete DMEM containing 100 nM Incucyte® Cytotox Red Dye.
Note: The Incucyte system can measure green and red fluorescence. Since the infected cells will express GFP, Cytotox Red is used. Otherwise, cell death can be measured using green fluorescent dyes such as Incucyte® Cytotox Green or Yoyo-1.
Scan the plate using the Incucyte live cell imaging system every hour for up to 24 h. Representative images of GFP expression by the virus and cell death by Cytotox Red is shown in Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7].
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1059-Fig7.jpg
Figure 7. Representative Incucyte images of L929 cells infected with the indicated recombinant viruses
Cells were infected with the indicated virus for 24 h in the presence of cytotox red. Infected cells are marked by green fluorescence. Note that cells infected with rVACV-GFP were Cytotox Red, which indicates cell death. By contrast, rVACV-GFP-vIRD infected cells had little cytotox red signals, which is consistent with virus-induced RIPK3 degradation and resistance to autocrine TNF-induced necroptosis.
Analyze the results using the Incucyte software version 2020B.

Note: Cell death is calculated by dividing the red fluorescent area (dying cells) over the green fluorescent area (infected cells) using the Incucyte software. If non-fluorescent viruses are used, the phase area can be used instead of the green fluorescent area. Alternatively, cell death can be calculated using the number of fluorescent objects. Other methods of cell death measurement such as flow cytometry can also be used for cell death measurement.
